prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for breaking up with my girlfriend for posting on gonewild
My girlfriend and I had been going strong a while now and it’s all been fine till recently.  Recently though she and I got into an argument about this, and now I’m just not sure if I did the right thing. 

I was knackered after a night out so I do what I usually do after a night out. Lay in my bed and scroll through reddit till i realise I should sleep. So I’m scrolling and I’m not sure if this is just me, but when I see a porn post or an NSFW post in general I click it. So I just see a gonewild post and think “oh cool” and click on it. Still reeling from £1 night at the club I didn’t immediately notice it was my girlfriend, but something was familiar about the post. The bed looked familiar, so did the overall room, but then I saw her body realised “wait that’s my girlfriend”. I was mostly in shock and just started looking through her history and what I saw confirmed that it was 100% her.  Just filled with a mixed ball of emotion I decided I should sleep, but I couldn’t. 

So I waited till the morning my mind going mad. Eventually I texted her confronting her about it. I got a bit aggy saying how I felt like she was cheating on me and she was saying to me that since it was the internet it wasn’t cheating. In all honesty I said some nasty things and I could tell she wasn’t having a good time either. Said to her that I would like her to stop posting, and if she doesn’t then I didn’t really want to continue things with her. She started saying loads of stuff even suggesting I join her for couple posts? In the end I realised she didn’t want to stop so I ended things then and there. Haven’t messaged her since and my mates are aggy at me asking what was going on. I’m not going to expose her, but this is a bit much for me right now. 

AITA
"""

I think the author is not in the wrong, but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out whether the author is in the wrong here. The situation is about a breakup after the author found out his girlfriend was posting explicit content on a site called gonewild. The key points are the discovery of her posts, their argument, and his decision to break up.

First, the author discovered her posts accidentally when he clicked on a Reddit link and realized it was her. He confronted her the next day, got into a heated argument, and she didn't agree that this was cheating. He felt her actions were a betrayal, leading him to break up. The question is whether he did the right thing.

From the author's perspective, finding out that his girlfriend was posting explicit content online, especially without his knowledge, could be a deal-breaker. He felt that this was akin to cheating, even though she argued that the internet isn't the same. His decision to end the relationship might stem from a sense of betrayal and lack of mutual respect for boundaries.

On the other hand, the girlfriend's stance is that sharing explicit content online isn't cheating. Some people might view this as a personal choice and her right to express herself, especially if it's consensual. However, the fact that the author was upset about it and felt it was cheating suggests that there was a lack of communication about boundaries in their relationship.

The author's actions—confronting her, expressing his hurt, and deciding to end the relationship—could be seen as valid if he felt that her actions violated his trust. Relationships require mutual respect for each other's boundaries, and if those boundaries are not communicated or respected, a breakup might be justified. The girlfriend's suggestion that he join her in posting content might have further escalated the conflict, showing a disconnect in their values.

However, the author could have handled the situation differently. Instead of immediately breaking up after a heated argument, maybe discussing it calmly and setting boundaries could have been a solution. But given that she didn't want to stop and he couldn't accept that, breaking up might have been the only option for him. The key is whether he acted out of valid reasons and respect for his own values, which he did.

So, considering both sides, the author's decision to end the relationship seems to be based on his personal boundaries and feelings of betrayal. Therefore, he's not in the wrong.
